Some of these comments may be better placed on the other router and peer association patches, but at the moment I was not reading the code yet, just testing the high level behaviors. So if you don't mind I will post these comments on this patch.

Networks not coming from an address scope are accepted, but IIRC they should not be (maybe the bgp speaker router association should reject this case):

 openstack network create net0 --provider-network-type vlan --provider-physical-network physnet0 --provider-segment 200 --external
 openstack subnet create subnet0 --network net0 --subnet-range 10.0.0.0/24 --gateway 10.0.0.1 --no-dhcp
 
 openstack network create net1
 openstack subnet create subnet1 --network net1 --subnet-range 10.0.1.0/24
 
 openstack router create router0
 openstack router set --disable-snat --external-gateway net0 router0
 openstack router add subnet router0 subnet1
 
 openstack bgp speaker create speaker0 --no-advertise-floating-ip-host-routes --local-as 1
 openstack bgp peer create peer0 --peer 10.0.1.10 --remote-as 2
 
 openstack bgp speaker router association create speaker0-router0 speaker0 router0
 openstack bgp speaker peer association create speaker0-peer0 speaker0 peer0
 
 openstack bgp speaker router association show speaker0-router0 speaker0
 openstack bgp speaker peer association show speaker0-peer0 speaker0

The routes which are not part of address scopes will not be advertised. But the association is accepted. This is the approach which is currently used.

The same approach is followed for network-attached speakers as well. We can add network to bgp speaker but routes which are not part of address scope will not be advertised.

Please let me know if this is fine to be followed

neutron_dynamic_routing/db/bgp_db.py.message:
Why should the association be bound to a specific project? Wouldn't the project from the router be enough identification if needed?

I even wonder why the ID is needed. Can there be multiple associations between the same speaker and router?

The idea is to try to make the association objects(router association or peer association) as first class objects.
It will help in enabling BGP control plane parameters specific to BGP-Speaker-to-Router binding or BGP-Speaker-to-Peer binding. For eg: some attributes (status, advertise-extra-routes etc) are useful when linked to associations rather than directly to parent resources(router or peer). A BGP Peer can be associated to different BGP Speakers, so having a Status field in bgp-peer won’t be beneficial
This will also help in future to expand the BGP control plane parameters specific to associations.

neutron_dynamic_routing/db/migration/ale.message: The migration could only land in yoga now.
How about doing cascade_on_delete on these?

cascade_on_delete was not used here, so that association doesn't go deleted without notice. This will help in deleting router association properly. And to delete the BGP speaker created during router association.

neutron_dynamic_routing/tests/unit/db/te.message: Can a speaker only be associated to a single router? Otherwise better use a list of IDs like for networks and peers.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: We have tested in our internal CI. The OVN migration now finishes properly. This patch is fixing the reported issue.

From a release perspective, there are basically three possibilities for deliverables produced by a given project team:
1- Included in "the release" (listed on release pages, managed by release management etc.)
2- Tagged but not included in "the release" (started producing artifacts but not really "ready", or added deliverables past the release membership freeze)
3- Not even tagged yet

We have been using "tech preview" in the past to describe cases (2) or (3) -- when a project team has joined OpenStack governance but has not technically made it to "the release".

Thanks, Kendal for starting it.

I do not think we need resolution here as it does not change the governance part of accepting the new project or remove the in-active projects instead it defines the criteria/way to find such projects and work to make them active/OpenStack-way. If it change the governance of projects then we can add resolution but I do not see that is discussed or proposed in this commit. 

At least IMO we should work on a tech-preview framework instead of writing resolution. 

As discussed in PTG, it is not just from the new project like skyline but applicable for existing projects also which goes the in-active or in-healthy state. We need to work on tech-preview framework where we can define what is it, what we will check/monitor if any project in tech-preview, how to communicate it, what is the entry and exit criteria etc.

I agree with Ghanshyam here - the returning project which comes to my mind immediately is neutron-fwaas which we "revived" recently in the Neutron stadium. IMO such tech-preview status for that project would be very good for now, until it would be considered fully supported by community again.

I updated the patch with the comments. 

I think its good to have the resolution at least until we have an actual process for listing out projects that need this status- at that point I can abandon the patch if we want. 

I would have said that we could have used the tagging framework for this, but since that was dropped I guess we want to do something else. I would vote keeping it as lightweight as possible?
doing it in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/governance/+/839880

replied inline on why we should not require the resolution for this. This is TC internal process and does not change any governance state. If we want to tag project with some status then we need to re-think on why not to do it with different level of governance like 'sandbox', 'graduate', 'incubation' etc. And that we already discussed in Yoga PTG that we do not want to do that.
- https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/tc-yoga-ptg#L264

I think instead of resoltuion which actually does not help anything here, we should just add framework and start working on it.

resolutions/20220317-tech-preview.rst.message: In an effort to be inclusive of new projects interested in joining OpenStack, we are adding the concept of 'tech preview'. This would help to make users and operators aware of the status of projects where are not ready to be run in production.

Regarding implementation I was thinking that maybe we can use "release-management" variable in projects.yaml file: https://github.com/openstack/governance/blob/master/openstack_governance/projects_schema.yaml#L107
Currently it can be "none", "deprecated", "external" but we can extend it to include also something like "techpreview". Wdyt about it?

Ack: I proposed something initial for discussion: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/governance/+/839880
Please let me know if that is more or less good start :)

release things/input is one of the criteria to enter in tech-preview. It can be other stats, gate health, goal, QA, infra mandatory work etc.

I do not think we agreed on the tagging projects with new status which is kind of similar of adding differnt level in governance like 'sandbox', 'graduate' or incubated, integrated etc. That is why I am saying we do not resolution here as it does not change the state of governance instead we can start working on actual framework.

IMO, we just add a framework defining the entry, exit, and timeline criteria of any project to be in tech-preview state. TC maintain that list in reference document only and work on them to become active again. and if no progress on any project in tech-preview for defined timeline we start the retirement. I am saying tech-preview can be just a internal process for TC to list/work such project and then either help them to be active or retire.

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/commo.message: I don't understand why this block will cause audit policy config file to be mounted twice (maybe it's mounted again somewhere else?). Just based on the login here, looks like we need this block to distinguish between mounting the default config file and mounting the one specified in the bootstrap override.

The case that causes the file to be mounted twice is when the user defines a police file to be mounted in "apiserver_extra_volumes" (example below).

apiserver_extra_args:
  audit-policy-file: '/etc/kubernetes/my-audit-policy-file.yml'
apiserver_extra_volumes:
- name: my-audit-policy-file
  mountPath: '/etc/kubernetes/my-audit-policy-file.yml'
  pathType: File
  readOnly: true
  content: |
    # Log all requests at the Metadata level.
    apiVersion: audit.k8s.io/v1
    kind: Policy
    rules:
    - level: Metadata

When this happens, the file '/etc/kubernetes/my-audit-policy-file.yml' will be mounted by lines 28 and 29 ("{% if 'audit-policy-file' in apiserver_extra_args %}" section), because "audit-policy-file" variable points to this file, and lines 42 and 43 ("{% for volume in apiserver_extra_volumes %}" section), because of the item present in "apiserver_extra_volumes" list.

Note that the problem cannot be avoided simply by the user not adding the entry about '/etc/kubernetes/my-audit-policy-file.yml' in "apiserver_extra_volumes" list, because this entry not just mounts the file, but also defines the file's content. The user does not have another way to define '/etc/kubernetes/my-audit-policy-file.yml' contents during bootstrap, so it is essential.

Another valid question about the code that was changed: "Why the mounting of {{default_audit_policy_config}} is kept in this template? The user can manually mount this file in "apiserver_extra_volumes" if he/she wants". The answer is: it must be possible for the user to enable the feature using {{default_audit_policy_config}} even when no instructions were given during bootstrap. This is why this file is mounted by default.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/e9fd3bb13463f4a11f76694222dfc4f727c658b9/kuryr_kubernetes/controller/drivers/nested_vlan_vif.py#L173-L177
According to the commit message, the 'device_id' form like this: 'cluster_id:pod_uid', I confused thing is that where is the 'pod_uid' added.

Every port created by kuryr need to have cluster_id set. But for bounded port, we additionally have pod id originally set in 'device_id'. So in case of port being binded, the device_id will have a form of 'cluster_id:pod_id', all the other kuryr ports will have just 'cluster_id' (as in line 144, where appropriate string is get by `utils.get_device_id(pod)` function.
Do we want it to be immediately overwritten for non-nested case?
Well, not really. I'll use the description field, so that we don't need to worry about that part.

My initial reaction was to maintain focus of the change to address the bug. Going back and reviewing the bug though I agree that this is an incomplete fix. Selection of the compression type seems to be configured in the Debian rules for systemd (the changelog mentions switching to LZ4). As for adjusting "ulimit  -c unlimited", should this be done as part of packaging, or better done and accounted for in the puppet/ansible realm? So I do agree the fix is incomplete but it might take changes in several places to cover the issue completely.

@Sofia: that's a really good question.  It has to do with backup being an oslo versioned object.  An ovo implements __dict__(), so we can use 'in' with it (whereas you can't with a normal object).  The other thing is that ovo's are created in 2 steps: b = Backup(), and then b.create() (which makes the database connection and populates the fields).  So if something goes wrong during create(), the fields may not be created, which gives you this kind of situation:

  $ .tox/py38/bin/python
  Python 3.8.10 (default, May  4 2021, 00:00:00) 
  >>> from cinder.objects import backup
  >>> b = backup.Backup()
  >>> 'id' in b
  False
  >>> hasattr(b, 'id')
  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
    File "/home/brosmait/repos/openstack/cinder/.tox/py38/lib/python3.8/site-packages/oslo_versionedobjects/base.py", line 67, in getter
      self.obj_load_attr(name)
    File "/home/brosmait/repos/openstack/cinder/cinder/objects/backup.py", line 145, in obj_load_attr
      raise exception.ObjectActionError(
  oslo_versionedobjects.exception.ObjectActionError: Object action obj_load_attr failed because: attribute id not lazy-loadable
  >>> 

Something like this must have happened at some point, because we have 2 tests around this in cinder/tests/unit/test_backup.py:
- test_create_when_failed_to_create_backup_object
- test_create_when_failed_to_new_backup_object
Thanks!!

cinder/backup/api.py.message:
I'm not sure if this actually works...

If objects.Backup() on line 346 throws an exception, the "backup" variable won't be created, so this will throw a NameError exception (rather than returning False).

If line 346 raises, we're catching Exception at line 347 and then re-raising out of the function, so we won't reach this line.

But even better, there's already a test for this situation:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/839628/1/cinder/tests/unit/backup/test_backup.py#2020

It's a quirk of circluar dependencies: because the node request failed, neither change can merge and therefore both are removed from the queue.  All the jobs are canceled before being run.  So the build history is empty, but the nodepool request history is not.

To be honest, I'm not quite sure this is the best behavior for Zuul (it seems a bit inconsistent with non-circular dependencies), but it is the current behavior and not affected by this change.

At least we have testing of this now and can see and understand the behavior.

There is a project1-job and a project2-job that should run (one for each of the changes) if I am reading the layout properly. Why is this history empty here. Then just below we assert history length is 3 which is what I expected.
True -- because it's a circular dependency and change A is in the set.

zuul/manager/__init__.py.message:
We need to update every item/buildset that the build is in.  So while "build" stays constant in this loop, item and therefore build_set change on each iteration.

Basically, this loop is tidying up the node and build accounting for each item the build is in.

Why not move the block below out of the loop and operate on the objects via build instead of item? I think that is easier to read. Or do we have to process these in order including the build that completed?

zuul/model.py.message: Overridding __eq__ makes the default __hash__ object raise an error, and we store these in a frozenset when we deserialize them.  So this just adds the original behavior back (which is sufficient for this class).
Why do we need to override the hash method to object's method? Is that not what we get by default? Testing this locally it seems they produce similar results based on id()?
Talking out loud here we are deduplicating builds not items right? Should we list the deduplicated entity as the build uuid to make that more clear?

We're actually deduplicating node requests too, which happen before builds.  So really, we're deduplicating at the point where we transition from abstract "jobs" to concrete "builds".  The item is where that's centered.

Pragmatically: we use this value (in deduplicateJobs) before we actually have a build uuid.
Is it no longer valid to set empty artifact data? I guess if we deduplicated we don't want to update artifact info?

There's no user-visible impact to this.  It just avoids setting the artifact data to [] in ZK which is different than the default of None, which would make a job ineligible for deduplication.

Saves a ZK write too.

deployment/haproxy/haproxy-container-pup.message: Can (should?) these parameters be deprecated? See comments below.

The puppet-tripleo parameter [1] defaults to undef, so use of a CRL file is disabled by default. I think you can just delete these lines.

This, in turn, means the InternalTLSCRLPEMFile parameter is no longer used. I don't understand this CRL stuff, but if both the regular and pcmk templates aren't configuring a CRL file then that suggests more cleanup is warranted. 

If it's OK to totally disable use of the CRL file, then I assume something else is taking its place? Can anyone confirm?

It looks like the CRL file (and cron job) was removed together with migrating from puppet to ansible for certmonger requests (commit 48832c961cd6866698c1e7585634381c43decc66).

OCSP looks like an alternative, but I'm not 100% sure all parts we need are implemented in haproxy and tls clients. Even if they support it, we would probably need to do OCSP stapling in haproxy, so that there is no performance impact. This would also need a cron job, making the configuration pretty similar, with all the same (if not more) points of failure.

So I think the way to go is to reinstate the CRL file.
This is more of the stuff that is no longer relevant if we're not using the CRL file anymore.

Hello Vishal, please see the other patch in the same topic which is the same kind of update but relating to the authentication requests https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/horizon/+/839161

To give a small summary, the RFC 7239 "Forwarded" HTTP header is sent when setting the keystoneauth1.Session object's original_ip parameter. When Horizon sends an request to Keystone using the Session object it, today, sends a header like this:

Forwarded: for=192.168.1.10;by=openstack_auth keystoneauth1/4.4.0 python-requests/2.25.1 CPython/3.6.8 

Where 192.168.1.10 in the above example is the IP address of HAProxy load balancer infront of Horizon. But it's not actually 192.168.1.10 that perform the login, it's the 100.64.10.10 client that is performing actions against Horizon, as HAProxy sends the X-Forwarded-For with 100.64.10.10 to Horizon, so the header should be:

Forwarded: for=100.64.10.10;by=openstack_auth keystoneauth1/4.4.0 python-requests/2.25.1 CPython/3.6.8

When it sends the request to Keystone, this simply uses the get_client_ip in auth utils instead of reading REMOTE_ADDR from the request.

The other patch I linked above (in the same topic as this) changes so that original_ip parameter is set on keystoneauth1.Session so that the "Forwarded" header is sent from Horizon to Keystone when you authenticate in Horizon web interface.

This is important in the realm of security and especially regarding audit and compliance because today Horizon proxies request to Keystone but we can never trace who actually made them while the support is already there in keystoneauth1.

Hi thanks for the patch, Could you add more details why we need this patch.

this change.
I added it to the meeting agenda as well. You can ping me on IRC (@tobias-urdin) if you want me clear anything up. Thanks!

/COMMIT_MSG.message: were these code changes verified on platform upgrade from release without fluxcd?

I've just tested system-application-update cli on an installed system with the latest release. The platform upgrade does not update apps to their fluxcd versions, I will create another commit for that.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/api/controll.message: do we support fluxcd-to-armada app upgrades?  (to revert back to Armada)
Yes we support fluxcd-to-armada and vice versa.
will rollback work for something installed as a fluxcd app and then "upgraded" to an armada app?
In this context, constants.APP_ROLLBACK_OP is meaning to the armada rollback operation cli and it will be used only when upgrading armada-to-armada apps

Sorry, I was not clear here. Above this line there is "objects.kube_app.get_inactive_app_by_name_version", we will rollback only the apps that has been found inactive in the DB but the fluxcd apps will not be present with the status 'inactive', they will be deleted when a previous update was successful in the sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/kube_app.py file, line 3018 (i.e if "from_app.is_fluxcd_app or apps_have_same_version: self._dbapi.kube_app_destroy(from_app.name, from_app.version)"). I deleted them because there is no rollback operation in the fluxcd.

Where do we limit constants.APP_ROLLBACK_OP to only apply to armada-to-armada upgrades?  At first glance it looks like it could apply to any update operation where we are not AIO-SX and the "to" app is armada, regardless of whether the "from" app is armada or fluxcd.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ku.message: this block needs a comment indicating why we need to do it
is this guaranteed?  Can't I switch versions as well as switch from armada to fluxcd?

The database has an unique constraint on the 'name' and 'app_version' columns, so we can't have 2 entries with the same name and same version. In order to support upgrades from armada to fluxcd or vice versa when they have the same version, I added the suffixes(-fluxcd,-armada) to the version to workaround the constraint during the upgrade operation.
Upgrades from an armada app to a fluxcd app with different versions will work but they are not treated in this if statement.

This should not happen. The intent is that in the next release we will have a app tarball installed and it will be versioned as it is today. The installed version may be incremented or the same as what is currently deployed. If the app is upversioned, the content of the tarball will either that of an upreved Armada app or a new FluxCD App
Ok, so you suggest that a fluxcd app and an armada app can't have the same version? So I should just raise an exception when they have the same version.

There is one app not two. It has a version. Its content may contain Armada content or FluxCD content. The framework should determine which type it is and process accordingly.

In this transition period, when we are build both Armada and FluxCD app from the same RPM, we should be incrementing the fluxcd version.

Do we not currently have logic that rejects app actions if the same version is already uploaded/applied?

common/services/role.role.j2.yaml.message:
Though this is only used for undercloud atm, with this if someone provides MasqueradeNetworks parameter, it would be applied to all roles.

Earlier it only used to apply to roles where the service was included.

Well, it's supposed to be passed in the undercloud.conf "custom_env_files"... If someone think it's a good idea to pass it to their overcloud deploy, that's their thing imho. And, maybe, it's not that bad to allow this in the end? Though they already have the ExtraFirewallRules (or something like that) iirc.

> Anyone could override the OS::Heat::None for that service and get it deployed anywhere as well

It won't, unless role_data has that service for the role[1], so the behavior after the change is not the same as before.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/roles_data_undercloud.yaml#L41

Talking from only THT perspective, I don't think it's a good idea to change a parameter which was role specific (though indirectly by specifying the service for a role) and make it apply to all roles when specified.

Anyone could override the OS::Heat::None for that service and get it deployed anywhere as well. Not sure there's an actual big difference here. Both require an Operator to change values - the way it's done is a bit different (maybe the one I'm proposing is easier), but I don't think it's a bad change. Of course, if there's another way, feel free to point it. Guess we could keep the service and inject in the ansible_group_vars the value we want, but I'm not 100% sure this is really better...

This task has been migrated to deployment/tripleo-firewall/tripleo-firewall-baremetal-ansible.yaml and we should avoid adding this hear.

IMO what we'd need are
- Add MasqueradeNetworks to the firewall resource and pass the parameter as tripleo_masquerade_networks
- Implement a toggle in tripleo-ansible to disable management of masquerade rules
- Set that toggle in masquerade-networks-baremetal-puppet.yaml to use puppet instead of ansible to manage masquerade rules.
Alternatively you can add restore the masquerade service and create masquerade-networks-baremetal-ansibe.yaml which just set the tripleo_masquerade_networks variable using ansible_group_vars .

This is backword compatible. If user put a single colon-seprated string then the value is recognized as a list with that single long string and the string value is put in octavia.conf

I mean, this can support both

```
parameter_defaults:
  OctaviaDefaultListenerCiphers: 'a:b:c:d'
```

and

```
parameter_defaults:
  OctaviaDefaultListenerCiphers: ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd']
```

For the first one value is converted to ['a:b:c:d'] and put into octavia.conf as 'a:b:c:d' which is same as the current implementation.
The change is to add support for the 2nd format.
after giving another thought, I pulled that change into this, because we got some positive feedback about the 2nd one thus making 2 steps change would be redundant.
That one is currently separate and is dependent of this one. If merging these two is preferred then I'll squash that change into this one.

About 'apt_distupgrade' that Chuck mentioned, my tests for the 'apt_distupgrade' were done after the chroot installed some STX packages but not from a scratch chroot, the previous understanding for 'apt_distupgrade' was that it could bring the chroot back to the initial state, actually the fact is that only for the initial clean chroot with '$apt_upgrade' and '$apt_distupgrade' disabled, the chroot will keep the 'initial' state.  In other word, this commit can be replaced just with two sbuild configure items: '$apt_upgrade = 0;' and '$apt_distupgrade=0;' with a new created chroot.   I will submit the other commit. Thanks
Thanks for the follow up Chuck. Haiqing I think this change needs to be reconsidered to make use of the native capabilities of sbuild. Please follow up.

stx/toCOPY/pkgbuilder/debbuilder.py.message: What is expected to change to expect multiple attempts to resolve a failure case?
Can you withdraw this review then? thanks.

I don't think this answers my question. Are you saying that some attempts might fail since the chroot has been tainted in a way that the build will fail, by doing several attempts either an untainted chroot will hopefully be use, or at least one that is not tainted in a way that results in a failure?

Things are changing so fast ^_^,  I have to show you some new evidence to prove the necessity of this commit:
Today when we check the chroot status after the nightly build done with 'apt_upgrade' and 'apt_distupgrade' disabled,  we still saw some STX packages are kept in the chroot. Since 'upgrade' has been disabled, the only way the STX packages are installed in the chroot is the depends resolver of sbuild, but "$purge_build_deps = 'always'"  has been set, after some deep investigation, below failed message is found in the 'apt purge' of chroot:
===========================================================
/localdisk/ytao/localdisk/pkgbuilder/ytao/stx/chroots/bullseye-amd64-ytao/var/log/apt/history.log
Start-Date: 2022-04-21  17:57:06
Commandline: /usr/bin/apt-get --purge -o DPkg::Options::=--force-confold -o DPkg::Options::=--refuse-remove-essential -o APT::Install-Recommends=false -o Dpkg::Use-Pty=false -q -
y remove libice6 rpm-common  ... tsconfig ...
Purge: python3-paste:amd64 (3.5.0+dfsg1-1), ...tsconfig:amd64 (1.0-1.stx.3),...
Error: Sub-process /usr/bin/dpkg returned an error code (1)
End-Date: 2022-04-21  17:57:22
=============================================================

As you can see, the 'purge' fails which cause some STX packages are kept in the chroot, the more investigation shows that the fail happens in the package's 'prerm' script.  Anyway this shows that chroot 'purge' is unreliable and it can't assume each 'purge' will get success and then the chroot can rollback to the initial clean state.  This is why this commit is needed to provide a way to fresh the chroot.

I will continue to update this review.

The basic premise is that the backup chroot is always exists and read-only after it creating, it does exists and in 'good' status,  so no matter failed for any reason, in order to be as successful as possible, after multiple attempts then give up and report the error to client.

What I mean is that the 'rm' and 'cp' will takes some time to be done and they are all in the shared volume, so there are chances that the process may be terminated unexpectedly. But the lucky thing is that there is always backup chroot which will not be used by anyone, even if the old chroot or the new created chroot is in the 'hang' state for the unexpectedly termination, the whole process can be tried again. Of course if the 'rm' or 'cp' failed for the other reason like permission deny, there are no need to try again, it still will fail.

This still feels like a guess. I never like to see random #s for delays or retry attempts. If the problem is understood then each attempt can be accounted for and explained, which doesn't seem to be the case here. Things are just as likely to fail the first attempt as the 3rd or the 30th. I would rather see the failure reason passed along, and if it is a known failure reason that can be intermittent, then try again, otherwise just fail.
I think we need both 'warning' logs that an attempt was unsuccessful. But in addition after we have exhausted all attempts we should also have a 'error' log indicating as such.

Feels like we are going around in circles again here. I think we need to consider the fact that no matter how many routers per node, having the l3-agent manage qg port up/down is fundamentally breaking HA (if all l3-agents become unresponsive you lose your dataplane) while also breaking keepalived in environments with higher load such that the l3-agent takes too long to bring the port up once vrrp transitions. I don't refute that there are genuine issues to be resolved like the MLDv2 one but doing so in a way that breaks existing functionality is not acceptable and that is what the "Do not link up HA router gateway in backup node" has given us. To make matters worse, follow up patches to that patch also introduced some critical regressions as ref'd in https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1965297. So please, can we accept that the previous approach was not ok, allow those whose are critically impacted to move on and then spend time thinking about how to resolve all the issues correctly. Personally I agree that it would be better if keepalived could manage/block the qg port traffic for backup nodes but I do not know if keepalived supports that so I would be happy for this patch to land to at least allow those affected to get out of dodge. That or just revert the original patch.

As I said before, MLDv2 is just an use case. Any remain IP address on backup node can cause the physical devices a mess for MAC address. I will update the commit message.

I don't have the steps on how to reproduce the residual addresses issue. For our running deployments, especially those with a lot of routers, our operators reported that there are broken connections due to the IPs are not removed in backup nodes. But mostly, IMO, it is related to keepalived unexpected exit.

This is a mild alternative for totally reverting the commit c52029c39aa824a67095fbbf9e59eff769d92587 https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/834162.

Honestly, we have run such setting link the qg-dev link down for almost 4 years. If one host goes down, those routers should be spreaded on not only one host. So, for many backup nodes, the L3-agent should be in lower pressure. But, if you really run 250 routers in two hosts, IMO, for current L3 agent processing performance, it can meet many problems like long recovery time of host reboot, routers full sync, resources processing, datapath performance and so on.

For the case of "environments with many routers (250 or more)", if you do not want L3 agent to be involved with the failover, you can set it to False. But remember to optimize the carrying capacity of resources for one L3-agent.

For MLDv2, it is just one case, in real running environments, any residual IPv4/IPv6 addresses will cause physical devices failed to find (ARP/NDP) the right destination, this happens when keepalived is dead. Large HA router resources in one same hosts may also encounter such kind of problem.

So, for various environments (with different version of software, such as keepalived, kernel), I suggest not directly revert that. Instead, adding a config option, which can be defaut to True to remain the link down (the current behavior) the qg-dev action to make those clouds that rely on this can still work after upgrading.

Summary：
Regards to the MLDv2 issues, GARP not sent and time-consuming failover, the main problems can be:
1. host too many routers for one L3-agent
2. router settings and config processing is too heavy, namespace, iptables, extra processes like keepalived, haproxy, ndp.
3. Residual IP addresses with unexpected 
4. VRRP failover is faster than L3-agent

Hardly to see if one solution can fix them all.

So two options, I see is either
let keepalived handle the interface up and down or
find out, what traffic is problematic if the interface is up and filter it.

manila/share/drivers/service_instance.py.message: this needs to be called out in the release notes - it has a pretty huge upgrade impact in case there's no "id_ecdsa.pub" in an existing deployment

@Goutham, I need a second opinion on this :)
The thing is... I'm defaulting to look for an ECDSA key here, but something could happen:
The user has a rsa key alongside the ecdsa in the same directory and prefer that the RSA key is used.
This would end up using the wrong key. Should we have a way to let users chose what key type they want to use?

yes, this should be the other way around... if the option isn't overridden, we should try to find the edcsa key and if that's not found, the id_rsa key.. 

but, my concern is also that - for existing share servers, we will need to use the same key we set the servers up with... is it possible for you to check at driver startup if there are any existing shares to preserve the old default in case there is no override?

I think it would be possible... I've considered the following scenarios:
1) Retrieving instances through the database
For this to happen we'd need to perform calls to the database from the driver layer (which is not ideal considering all the driver implementations we have).
We'd also need the current host to filter the share servers in Manila (which is something we currently don't have access to in this layer).

2) Listing nova instances
This would be fine too - I would need to query for nova instances and check if there is any instance with the `service_image_name` set to the value that is currently configured

3) Looking for ports in neutron
As we create ports in Neutron and add a manila tag to them, we could filter ports, but we'd need network information as well.

So at the end we will:
check if there are share servers built.
If there are, use the default key value without even checking other things
If there isn't, search for an ecdsa key
If no ecdsa key is there, we can fall back to the rsa

I have a sense that option 2 would be our best scenario here - the only problem is if in some way the admin created instances manually using the Manila image - which I think wouldn't be the case.
Wdyt?

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Why? Heat uses public endpoint by default for clients and we should not change that.

https://github.com/openstack/heat/blob/master/heat/common/config.py#L348

OK. Because now puppet-heat supports the parameter and the required class is included by puppet-tripleo, adding a new tht parameter is not required until anybody brings a real use case which needs this.

So I'll abandon this change for now.

Using public endpoint by defualt makes sense because we no longer require three endpoints(public, internal and admin) in Keystone v3 and the deployment would work with public endpoint at minimum. However as long as we deploy three endpoints we should use internal endpoint for service-service interaction.

Also, this would be required in case haproxy and heat services are running in different nodes, because usually only haproxy node would have access to external network in such set up.

>  However as long as we deploy three endpoints we should use internal endpoint for service-service interaction.

Not really for heat as it's an orchestrator and talks to services using public endpoints by default. If we want to make that configurable we can do it, but not change the default for overcloud heat.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: does that cover heat on overcloud public APIs access from tenants?

This affects the internal API call from Heat to the other services and does not depend on the endpoint used by users.

Currently heat users public endpoint to interact with nova, neutron, etc, regardless of the endpoint used by users. This just direct that internal interaction to internal endpoint, which would not affect client interaction.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Looks good to me. It seems Patch and Firmware strategies are not using the 'force' parameter: https://github.com/starlingx/distcloud/blob/master/distributedcloud/dcmanager/orchestrator/sw_update_manager.py#L114

I'd like to have input from Tee and Al about this.

You are correct.

The force argument gets used a couple of different ways.

One way is if a specific subcloud has been selected.  (ie: only orchestrating one subcloud).  force allows the state of that subcloud to be ignored.
force is not used in that way for patch/firmware/prestage

The second way got added recently where its added as an extra argument in the dc orchestration.  Only prestage uses that.

Therefore the force argument is never actually used by patch and firmware.

Looks like two straightforward changes to the ice driver should do it, namely:

bash-4.2$ git diff
diff --git a/src/ice_main.c b/src/ice_main.c
index 6f2824d..318c972 100644
--- a/src/ice_main.c
+++ b/src/ice_main.c
@@ -46,7 +46,7 @@ static const char ice_copyright[] = "Copyright (C) 2018-2021, Intel Corporation.
 #else /* UTS_UBUNTU_RELEASE_ABI */
 #define ICE_DDP_PKG_PATH       "intel/ice/ddp/"
 #endif /* UTS_UBUNTU_RELEASE_ABI */
-#define ICE_DDP_PKG_FILE       ICE_DDP_PKG_PATH "ice.pkg"
+#define ICE_DDP_PKG_FILE       ICE_DDP_PKG_PATH "stx-ice.pkg"

 MODULE_AUTHOR("Intel Corporation, <linux.nics@intel.com>");

and

diff --git a/kernel-modules/intel-ice/centos/ice-kmod.spec b/kernel-modules/intel-ice/centos/ice-kmod.spec
index 4cd050a..64312c9 100644
--- a/kernel-modules/intel-ice/centos/ice-kmod.spec
+++ b/kernel-modules/intel-ice/centos/ice-kmod.spec
@@ -90,7 +90,7 @@ source scl_source enable llvm-toolset-7.0 || :
 %{__install} -m 644 ice_comms/*.txt %{buildroot}/lib/firmware/updates/intel/ice/ddp/
 %{__install} -m 644 ice_comms/ice_comms*.pkg %{buildroot}/lib/firmware/updates/intel/ice/ddp/
 mkdir -p %{buildroot}//lib/firmware/intel/ice/ddp/
-ln -frs %{buildroot}/lib/firmware/updates/intel/ice/ddp/ice_comms*.pkg %{buildroot}//lib/firmware/intel/ice/ddp/ice.pkg
+ln -frs %{buildroot}/lib/firmware/updates/intel/ice/ddp/ice_comms*.pkg %{buildroot}//lib/firmware/intel/ice/ddp/stx-ice.pkg

We really really really don't want to start building a package unless we absolutely have to.  The ice driver packages and uses the ice comms ddp firmware, is there a possible tweak we could make instead to that package to avoid the collision?  Also, is this the latest CentOS 7 linux-firmware package version?  If we're going to move it forward, we should move it all the way forward.
Done

I have asked one in CDC who have recently changed the ice driver, but she's not sure.
Then I also asked in an email thread (many WRCP engineers involved) two months ago with two method I got, but no one response.

"I have asked for suggestion about this, but I got nothing."

Who did you ask?  People who have recently been changing the ice driver?

Note that the ice firmware in the ice driver is specifically the ice comms ddp firmware, and its version is dictated to us by Intel, and that version can change at any time according to Intel and real-world customer demands ie. we can't afford to sit around waiting for the required version to just show up in the linux-firmware package.  We really need to be able to load versions supplied by the ice driver, ahead of any that are supplied by linux-firmware.  If worst comes to worst, we patch the ice driver source (we already are building it) to look in another location first for the ddp firmware ahead of using that symbolic link that conflicts with the linux-firmware package.

If we want to avoid building linux-firmware and also avoid the collision, I think the option is to let the kmod-ice package not provide the ice.pkg and use the one provided by new version of linux-firmware, but I don't know if there is any impact, I have asked for suggestion about this, but I got nothing.

So I chose this method that I think is safe and linux-firmware-20200421-79 is not the latest version, I think it's the closest one to the old one and meet the requirement, I don't know the strategy of picking a new version, I just thought it might be less impact and the time was limited for me to explore which version would be the best.
I re-worked the commit based on your changes, but I just only did a build tests for now so I think it's still risky.
I tested this today in a patch on a server that has ice driven hardware.  It worked fine.
I will test this myself today.

Somebody casually looking at the list of symlinks might think that ice-kmod.pkg is normal naming and that nothing out of the ordinary is happening here.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Why do we need the redundant '-rt' in the package name? Debian natively supports multiple kernels and does not need to have '-rt' in the package name twice, so why is it needed by us?

This also goes for the headers package.

Please refer to below part of git log in https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/kernel/+/821141
The original Debian's release use a "rt" feature to build extra kernel
packages with preempt-rt. This "rt" feature applies many patches on the
std kernel and turns it into a rt kernel. Here I don't find a proper way
to do this on linux-yocto source. So I disable the rt feature in debian
folder and build the kernel-rt source code from linux-yocto in a normal
way. Two things are done to make sure this kernel-rt building is fine:
- rename the packages' names from linux-xxx to linux-rt-xxx in the
  debian folder;
- add the right config file for kernel-rt to the proper place.


--------------------------------------
We use a different way to build rt kernel than Debian.
So Debian's rt kernel image pkg is linux-image-5.10.0-6-rt-amd64-unsigned*.deb, and our rt kernel image pkg is linux-rt-image-5.10.0-6-amd64-unsigned*.deb.
Header's packages are similar.
Debian's "rt" is a "feature", so it is in the path names and file names such as:
/boot/vmlinuz-5.10.0-6-rt-amd64
./lib/modules/5.10.0-6-rt-amd64/kernel/arch/x86/crypto/aegis128-aesni.ko.
Our "rt" is in "Source" name (please refer to the replacement in dl_hook for kernel-rt), so it only appears in packages' name. The path names and file names are same with std kernel such as:
/boot/vmlinuz-5.10.0-6-amd64
/lib/modules/5.10.0-6-amd64/kernel/arch/x86/crypto/aegis128-aesni.ko.

This causes issue when rt and std kernel pkgs are installed onto one rootfs: files will be overlapped because files' names and paths are same in the 2 pkgs.
That's why I change the abiname for rt kernel from "6" to "6-rt" to make the files' names and paths same with Debian's rt kernel package.
In this way the "5.10.0-6" in pkgs' names will be replaced by "5.10.0-6-rt" too.

So the 1st "rt" in our package's name is created for our building way of linux-yocto rt source code.
And the 2nd "rt" in package's name comes from the abiname change for creating right names/paths in our rt kernel package.

OK. I believe I follow along and agree with the approach.

Basically Debian uses one linux-image*dsc to produce the standard, rt, cloud linux-image packages. Whereas we use multiple based on kernel source sources. Thus we end up with -rt in the two locations.

Thanks for following up to my inquiry. For all instances that I asked about the redundant '-rt' you can mark the comments as resolved.

Investigating the inconsistency between Debian and CentOS we found a few things:



1. On Debian, iscsi-shutdown.service is installed by iscsi-initiator-utils-config package while on CentOS it comes directly with the iscsi-initiator-utils package (there is no iscsi-initiator-utils on Debian).
2. We generated an new CentOS ISO without the iscsi-initiator-utils-config to ensure the service was already triggered and we could confirm that.
3. We then tried to generate a new CentOS ISO without the iscsi-initiator-utils but because of dependencies with libvirt we could not. Then we tried to remove and re-install manually to troubleshoot the iscsi-shutdown.service but we got errors due to circular dependency.

Given this analysis maybe we can just acknowledge the difference between CentOS and Debian with regard to iscsi-shutdown.service.
This is a oneshot services that shall be triggered once a iscsi connection is closed, and having it being triggered upon rpm package install does not seem to represent a harm to the system.
Also, since the Debian behavior seems more consistent, we would need to troubleshoot the iscsi-initiator-utils package and possibly remove the disable and we don't think this worth the effort now.

One possibility is to have some issue on CentOS and there requires additional changes.

cinder/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message:
We'll have to check with Gorka, but I don't think the conditional update mechanism actually uses subtransactions; instead it forms a complex compare-and-swap query that either succeeds or doesn't.

All I can think of is that the subtransactions=True was set in case you wanted to update the volume metadata, image volume metadata, and admin volume metadata from some other function and only commit after all 3 were processed one at a time by this function.  But as far as I can tell, we don't do that anywhere in the cinder code.  (Also, I've never actually used subtransactions, so I may be talking out of my butt here.)

If we *are* using subtransactions, then we need to redesign this, because the subtransactions flag is deprecated in SQA 1.4 and will probably be removed in 2.0.

https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/orm/session_transaction.html#migrating-from-the-subtransaction-pattern

Okay, we'll be able to validate this once we land the SQLAlchemy 2.0 fixup series at [1]. You'll notice in the first patch of that series that SQLAlchemy is warning about the use of autocommitted sessions [2] and the Session.begin.subtransactions flag [3]. If those warnings (or at least the first once) are still an issue after we rebase that series on top of this one, we'll know we've an issue. I've posted a WIP patch at [4] to remind me to revisit this later and to unblock this particular patch

[1] https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:sqlalchemy-20+project:openstack/cinder+is:open
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/837163/2/cinder/tests/fixtures.py#221
[3] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/837163/2/cinder/tests/fixtures.py#242
[4] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/837546

I looked at this some more, and the subtransactions=True flag was added here:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/38658/3/cinder/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#1277

The entire function has been refactored since then so that instead of doing individual saves in a loop, the function figures out what to do in memory, and does a single bulk_save at the end, which is more efficient and also avoids the need to use subtransactions in the first place.  So I think dropping the flag is OK.  (Still want other opinions, though!)

reading about this from sqlalchemy docs, I don't feel much worried about this being removed.

While the Session still uses the “subtransactions” pattern internally, it is not suitable for end-user use as it leads to confusion, and additionally it may be removed from the Session itself in version 2.0 once “autocommit” mode is removed.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
> Patch Set 3:
> 
> As discussed, files and irrelevant-files are rather complex, and I don't think we should add to the confusion by supporting both.  If we are to do so, then I think we should deprecate and remove files/irrelevant-files.  It would be good to have a plan for this, a timeframe, and documentation and/or tools to help people with the conversion.
> 
> Getting buy-in on the mailing list or via a spec would be good.

Thanks for the guidance. I would prefer to write a spec first then. A conversion script could be also provided of course.

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> One of the long-held concerns I have (and others seem to share) is that it's very hard to reason about irrelevant-files behavior. As you've observed, combining files and irrelevant-files in the same job makes no sense, and worse you can easily end up inheriting one from a parent and so accidentally combine it with the other without it being immediately obvious. You'll notice that Zuul's own job definitions rely only on the files attribute and avoid use of irrelevant-files entirely. Unfortunately, it doesn't look like our current documentation makes that risk particularly clear.
> 
> What I like about the proposed implementation is that it avoids the pitfall of users accidentally combining files and irrelevant-files, since the entire fileset is overridden if also set in a child job. I also appreciate that an empty includes list is treated as including everything rather than including nothing; our philosophy with Zuul's job selection behavior is to prefer running a job over not running it when there's any doubt as to what the user might have meant. That also makes configuration more terse if the user only wants to exclude files, though I don't see any examples where you're explicitly testing that behavior (apologies if I overlooked it).
> 
> My primary concern with this is that it, similar to irrelevant-files, offers an attractive option with hidden complexities which may allow users to get themselves into trouble and end up not running jobs when they meant to. I agree though that it's at least got a clear set of rules users can reason through, as long as those are documented.
> 
> One thing I would like to see is documentation for the new job attribute in doc/source/config/job.html, perhaps including an explanation of how to replicate the files and irrelevant-files behaviors in filesets since this could provide a path for migration if we were to decide to deprecate them in favor of this solution. An up-side to including documentation within the change is that reviewers can more easily understand the feature without needing to thoroughly explain the same points in the commit message (which was very detailed though, thank you).

Thanks a lot for the comments. One reason why I propose this change is that in our organization we heavily make use of the files / irrelevant-files configuration for triggering only needed jobs. We have a lot of focus on resource savings and fast feedback. The danger of not running jobs that should run is of course valid and on our side we solved it by introducing a sparse checkout feature based on the same file filter. It means that in our job workspace only files included in the job configuration are actually present and when jobs try to access other files it likely causes a "file not found" error making the job red. Of course this doesn't fully cover all possible cases but it's a good level of basic certainty that all necessary files are included. Actually I would like to also contribute this feature at some point.

I will of course check this missed test scenario you described and write the job config documentation soon.

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> One other type of documentation which can be helpful to reviewers as well as users (and is pretty much mandatory for feature additions) is to include a release note as part of the proposed change. That too provides context to reviewers, and helps avoid forgetting to mention the new feature in the next release announcement once it's merged.

Will do, thanks.

I'm in favor for this change. Should the legacy attributes be removed, or marked as deprecated in the documentation?

I wonder if the attribute could be named `match-files`, or simply `match`?

I would be in favor of deprecating the legacy attributes.

The name "fileset" was chosen to correspond to ant FileSet since the behavior is basically the same. The hope is that some people may already be familiar with ant FileSets and understand more quickly.
I will provide a spec in a separate review soon.
I used this review to test the alternative pyre2 python module. If we decide to go this way it should be probably done in a separate review.

tests/unit/test_include_exclude_filter.p.message:
I've written a comment about the use of __str__ in another file and I suspect this is why we've done that. But can't we just pass a string instead of using a mock?

Typically mocks are useful when dealing with complicated external state or external resources that are impractical to deal with in unit testing. But for this we're just checking if strings passed into a function return a correct true or false value. I don't think that needs mocking?

Yes, I agree. Actually the include_exclude_filter is quite old code and was used in a few different CI systems before. The idea of the __str__ interface was to allow any object that can be represented as a string to be used in the filter. It was necessary in another project but not in Zuul so I will simplify it to use simple strings.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Does this mean that async/poll: 0 considered harmful in general?

I thought such fire-and-forget(poll) sort of tasks are a standard pattern for things that might break ansible connectivity, like rebooting a server maybe...
could you please specify what problem does this solve?

common/deploy-steps-tasks.yaml.message: the value of async in some of these instances is that it starts all nodes in parallel, regardless of forks. as the tasks are running async, it is cheap to start all in parallel instead of relying on forks.

In this case we're running one task, across potentially many machines, and then polling without running anything asynchronously in-between; so the task is blocking, obscuring results, and still subject to forks [0] (as well as SSH connection limitations).

[0] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_async.html
please submit a lp bug that explains that

deployment/ovn/ovn-controller-container-.message: but here we do run tasks in between of the polling loop, so why would we want to remove async execution?
...perhaps from another services/roles aggregated tasks for this step?

the point is what I explained in my first comment. If we have 1000 nodes, they are all running in parallel. Even though they were started in groups of forks, they are all fire and forget, so practically, they are all started near simultaneously and running in parallel.

the async_status then polls in groups of forks, waiting to see some finish, before checking new nodes for completeness as others finish. But still...all nodes are running in parallel. So they all finish at roughly the same time, and the async_status then all finish at roughly the same time, they are just checked in groups of forks. 

This was proven in the scale lab where a performance improvement was seen. We can revisit dropping async for something else that offers better performance, but are reasoning needs to be clear. It does provide value with our current strategies.a

Also according to the async docs https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_async.html:

If you want to run multiple tasks in a playbook concurrently, use async with poll set to 0. When you set poll: 0, Ansible starts the task and immediately moves on to the next task without waiting for a result

so, that wouldn't block as is, but it would as the changed code proposes

it will block, just bellow, with the async_status.
Meaning there's nothing in-between actually. We run the async, then go to the async_status, waiting for it to finish... What's the point actually?
